contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox MLB player |name=Keith McDonald |position=[[Catcher]] |image= |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1973|2|8}} |birth_place=[[Yokosuka, Japan]] |debutdate=July 4 |debutyear={{By|2000}} |debutteam=[[St. Louis Cardinals]] |finaldate=September 28 |finalyear={{By|2001}} |finalteam=[[St. Louis Cardinals]] |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.333 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=3 |stat3label=[[Run batted in|Runs batted in]] |stat3value=5 |teams=<nowiki></nowiki> *[[St. Louis Cardinals]] ({{By|2000}}-{{By|2001}}) }} '''William Keith McDonald''' (born February 8, 1973 in [[Yokosuka (city)|Yokosuka]], [[Japan]]) is a former [[Major League Baseball]] [[catcher]] and right-handed batter. He made his debut with the [[St. Louis Cardinals]] in 2000. On July 4, 2000 McDonald became the third player in St. Louis history to hit a [[home run]] in his first major league [[At bat|at-bat]]. On [[2000 in sports|July 6]], he homered in his second at-bat, becoming only the second player in MLB history to hit HRs in each of his first two big league at bats. [[Bob Nieman]], in 1951, is the other. McDonald hit a third home run that year, and is the only player in MLB history to have more than one home run in a career, but no other hits. In his first season McDonald [[batting average|batted]] .429 (3-7), with three homers, five [[run batted in|RBI]] and three [[Run (baseball statistics)|runs]] in six games.
